Direct oxidation of cyclohexane to adipic acid in air over Co3O4@ZrO2 nanostructured catalyst Sonu Bhandari a b Rubina Khatun a b Mukesh Kumar Poddar a Anil Chandra Kothari a b Rajaram Bal a b ⁎ a Light Stock Processing Division, CSIR-Indian Institute of Petroleum, Dehradun, Uttarakhand-248005, India Light Stock Processing Division CSIR-Indian Institute of Petroleum Dehradun Uttarakhand 248005 India aLight Stock Processing Division, CSIR-Indian Institute of Petroleum, Dehradun, Uttarakhand-248005, India b Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research (AcSIR), Ghaziabad-201002, India Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research (AcSIR) Ghaziabad 201002 India bAcademy of Scientific and Innovative Research (AcSIR), Ghaziabad-201002, India ⁎ Corresponding author. Despite the vast industrial importance of adipic acid (AA), developing sustainable and selective catalysts for the oxidation of cyclohexane using air as an oxidant is a longstanding challenge for researchers. We have synthesized a Co3O4@ZrO2 nanostructured catalyst and found that it converts cyclohexane to AA directly in air without adding any additional reagent. Under mild, environmentally friendly, solvent-free conditions and without any initiators, the catalyst showed a conversion of ∼40% with a selectivity of ∼43% towards adipic acid. NH3-TPD analysis confirmed the presence of acidic sites on Co3O4@ZrO2. According to the findings, loading Co3O4 in the ZrO2 matrix generated a considerable increase in acidity (1.08 mmol/g), and the trend of different loading of cobalt followed the order: 5.4Co3O4@ZrO2 > 3.2Co3O4@ZrO2 > 2.5Co3O4@ZrO2 > 1.6Co3O4@ZrO2. The catalyst was thoroughly characterized by XRD, BET, HR-TEM, SEM, H2-TPR, XPS, NH3-TPD, Pyridine-IR, TGA, Raman, ICP-AES, UV–Visible and EPR spectroscopy. The recyclability and leaching test confirmed the true heterogeneous nature of the catalyst as there was no significant loss of catalytic activity even after 5 cycles. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Adipic acid Cyclohexane oxidation Air Solvent-free condition Co3O4 nanoparticles Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Adipic acid (AA), a monomer of the polymer nylon-6,6, is regarded as one of the top 50 globally useful chemicals. In the chemical industry, it is one of the most significant aliphatic dicarboxylic acids, with an estimated global market of more than 9.3 billion pounds by 2027 [1,2]. In the year 2013, around 3.5 million tonnes of AA were manufactured and recorded an annual increase rate of 5% over the previous five years [3]. AA is an important feedstock for many processes in the pharmaceutical, food, and chemical industries [4]. It has been widely used to produce polyamides, nylon-6,6, polyester, and polyurethane resins. In particular, almost 75 years after the first commercial adipic acid synthesis by DuPont, sustained interest in improving its manufacturing has motivated researchers to develop new ways and resources [5]. AA is produced industrially through a three-step process (Scheme 1) starting from benzene, where the initial step involves the catalytic reduction of benzene to cyclohexane with Ni-Al2O3 catalyst, followed by the oxidation of cyclohexane to KA oil (mixture of cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone) in the second step. The third and final step is the oxidation of KA oil (6 × 106 tons per year) with a surplus amount of nitric acid in the presence of Cu and NH4VO3 as catalysts [6,7]. The biggest disadvantage of this step is to control the selectivity of intermediate KA oil [8]. Pollutants such as N2O, NO, and NO2 emitted during this process not only act as hazards to the environment but also contribute to the greenhouse effect and ozone layer depletion [9,10]. It was estimated that adipic acid production accounts for a ∼10% rise in atmospheric N2O levels annually [11–13]. Using soluble salts of Na2WO4, Mn(Acac)2 and Co(OAc)2 as homogeneous catalysts, in particular, can enhance AA efficiency to 70–80% [14,15]. However, the process cannot be used commercially due to environmental concerns or the poor recovery and significant catalyst leaching that was noticed despite higher AA yields. Therefore, the single-step solvent-free conversion of cyclohexane to AA using environmentally benign oxidants, especially molecular O2, is still challenging for researchers. There were numerous attempts to advance highly efficient and ecologically sound strategies for the commercial production of AA without producing N2O using various noble and non-noble metal-based oxide catalysts, as shown in Table S1 (Supporting Information). The oxidation of cyclohexane has been investigated using molecular oxygen over heterogeneous based catalysts such as Anderson-type polyoxometalates [16], Au-TiO2 [17], VPOCeO2 [18], Au-GOS [19], Au−Pd/TiO2 [20], Mn/HTS-1 [13], microporous FeAlPO-31 [11] and WFeCoO(OH) [21]. However, most of the cases used tert‑butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) as an initiator and acetonitrile as a solvent, making the process costly, energy-intensive, and non-greener. With a WFeCoO(OH) catalyst, Jagadeesan et al. recently demonstrated a very high cyclohexane conversion rate and good selectivity, but during each recyclability test, cyclohexane conversion and AA selectivity were decreased, and at the same time, organic solvent acetone was also used. [21]. Although there were several reports in the literature, the conversion of cyclohexane to AA in a single step using molecular oxygen as an oxidizing agent over a heterogeneous catalyst is rarely reported. In recent years, considerable attention has been deployed to developing reusable, easily available, cost-effective and new catalytic materials for cyclohexane oxidation. Nanocrystalline materials recently attracted the interest of researchers in various disciplines owing to their inherent size-dependent characteristics and their significant technological application [22–26]. These nanocrystalline materials have size-dependent features and outstanding electrical, optical, magnetic, mechanical and chemical capabilities that cannot be accomplished with bulk materials [27,28]. Zirconium oxide is among the most significant ceramic materials having numerous applications due to its excellent electrical, mechanical, thermal and optical properties [27,29]. Depending on the preparation method and its wide bandgap of 5–7 eV, zirconia has been effectively used to fabricate sensing applications, metal oxide semiconductors, ceramic devices, fuel cell electrolytes, and catalyst support material [30]. Cobalt is an outstanding doping species due to its abundant electronic states, and it has the property to retain the electronic structure by substituting Co2+ on the host lattice without causing substantial distortions in the oxide framework [29,30]. According to previous research, achieving a high selectivity to AA requires combining redox and acidic sites on the catalyst [11,12,21]. In the present work, we report the preparation of Co3O4 nanostructure supported on nanocrystalline ZrO2; and it was found that the catalyst shows ∼ 40% cyclohexane conversion with ∼ 43% selectivity towards adipic acid in the presence of 10 bar air pressure at 130 °C. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Zirconium (IV) oxynitrate hydrate, cobalt (II) nitrate hexahydrate, urea, ethylene glycol, cyclohexane, acetone and trimethyl sulfonium hydroxide solution was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Co. and used without any further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Co3O4@ZrO2-based nanostructures were synthesized using the precursors cobalt (II) nitrate hexahydrate and zirconium (IV) oxynitrate hydrate, respectively. In a typical synthesis method, 4.39 g zirconium (IV) oxynitrate hydrate and 0.29 g cobalt (II) nitrate hexahydrate were dissolved in 40 ml double-distilled water and 40 ml ethylene glycol with constant stirring. To the continuously stirred solution, urea solution (1molar in water) was added, where urea is used as a precipitating agent. The resultant solution was placed in a stainless-steel autoclave with Teflon lining. The autoclave was then sealed and kept at 90 °C for 20 h. The material was repeatedly washed with ethanol and distilled water (to remove any ions that might have remained in the products by centrifugation). The material was collected and dried overnight in an oven at 80 °C. Finally, it was calcined for 5 h in an air environment at 550 °C to get the final catalyst. Different Co3O4 loaded (1.6%, 2.5%, 3.2% and 7.7%) catalysts were also synthesized using the same preparation method. All the catalysts were denoted as xCo3O4@ZrO2, where x is the loading percentage of cobalt. ICP-AES analysis was used to determine the percentage of cobalt in the final composition. The techniques used for catalyst characterization are provided in the Supporting Information. 2.3 Catalytic activity measurement The catalytic oxidation of cyclohexane was performed in a 100 mL batch reactor equipped with an overhead stirrer (Parr reactor, USA). Generally, the reaction was performed using cyclohexane (0.92 mol) and 0.1 g Co3O4@ZrO2 solid catalyst. A stirring speed of 1200 rpm and a reaction time of 8 h at a temperature of 130 °C were used unless otherwise stated. The influence of air pressure during cyclohexane oxidation was investigated in the 5–15 bar range. A photograph of the reactor is shown in Supporting Information Figure S1. The reactor was cooled to room temperature when the reaction was completed and filtered out. The quantitative analysis and identification of the products were carried out by GC and GCMS–, respectively. The following formulae were used to calculate the cyclohexane conversion, AA selectivity and AA yield. Conversion of cyclohexane (%) = moles of cyclohexane reacted / moles of cyclohexane initially used × 100 Selectivity of AA (%) = moles of AA formed / moles of cyclohexane reacted × 100. Yield of AA (%) = cyclohexane conversion (%) × AA selectivity (%) / 100 For sample preparation, the reaction mixture was diluted in 5 ml acetone in a GC vial and quantified the products by GC-FID. For better analysis of adipic acid, 200μL of product sample was derivatized with 100 μL of trimethylsulfonium hydroxide in the presence of an external standard acetone to acquire the adipic acid in the ester form [17]. The GC column and oven conditions are provided in the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization To determine the crystalline phase of the Co–Zr nanostructure catalyst, X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed, as indicated in Fig. 1 . Peaks at 2θ values of 19°, 31.2°, 36.8°, 44.8°, 55.6°, 59.3° and 65.2° correspond to the reflections of Co3O4 oxides was observed [JCPDS no. 78–1970, space group: Fd 3 ¯ m (227)] (Fig. 1a). Peaks at 2θ values of 30.16°, 34.9°, 35.07°, 50.4°, 50.5°, 60.07°, 63.2°, 74.4°, and 74.6° (JCPDS no. 88–1007, space group: P42/nmc (137)) also confirmed the presence of tetragonal ZrO2 (Fig. 1b). After cobalt loading, there was no indication of a cobalt-related peak or phase shift, revealing that Co-metal did not alter the crystal phase of ZrO2. The enhanced crystallinity of the catalyst with higher cobalt loading up to 2.5 wt.% was shown by the increased intensity of the XRD peaks at 2θ values of 50.5°, 60.07°, and 63.2° corresponding to the planes (112), (200) and (211) respectively (Fig. 1c-1d). Scherrer equation was used to determine the crystallite size, and a mean crystallite size of 13 nm was found for the 5.4Co3O4@ZrO2 catalyst, which was also supported by HR-TEM analysis. A significant shift of 2θ values (0.28°) was observed in Co3O4 loaded ZrO2 (Fig. 1a), indicating cobalt ions incorporated into the host zirconia lattice. The higher shift may be explained by the difference in ionic radii between zirconium and cobalt. As the concentration of Co3O4 increases, more cobalt ions replace zirconium ions. As zirconium ionic size (0.72 Å) is larger than that of Co (0.65 Å), the size of the crystallites is reduced when the host lattice of zirconium is substituted with Co [31,32]. So, Co3O4 loaded ZrO2 has a smaller crystallite size than pure ZrO2 suggesting the presence of oxygen vacancies at grain boundaries and in the interfaces. These vacancies hinder nanoparticles from developing further and creating a stress field [33]. The XRD pattern of a spent 5.4Co3O4@ZrO2 catalyst (Figure S2, Supporting Information) was similar to the fresh catalyst (Fig. 1f). Due to the low loading and smaller particle size (confirmed by HR-TEM analysis, discussed later), neither the fresh nor the spent 5.4Co3O4@ZrO2 catalysts showed any XRD peaks for any Co-species. Furthermore, no additional cobalt/zirconium oxide phases are revealed from XRD, demonstrating the purity of the material. The specific surface area and porosity of Co3O4, ZrO2 and 5.4Co3O4@ZrO2 were investigated by N2 adsorption-desorption measurements, and corresponding BJH plots are shown in Fig. 2 . 5.4Co3O4@ZrO2 exhibits type IV isotherms with a hysteresis loop, and may be corroborated to stacked holes by its nanoparticle nature (confirmed by HR-TEM analysis, discussed later). 5.4Co3O4@ZrO2 showed a surface area of 63.5 m2g−1, which is higher than that of pure ZrO2 (33.4 m2g−1) and pure Co3O4 (55.3 m2g−1) (Table 1 ). The surface area increases most, probably due to a reduction in crystallite size after the incorporation of Co3O4 in the ZrO2 lattice. This may explain why Co3O4 loaded over ZrO2 has better catalytic performance than pure ZrO2 and Co3O4. The HR-TEM images of the 5.4Co3O4@ZrO2 material, as indicated in Fig. 3 , show that the material is almost spherical in shape and homogenous in size. Fig. 3(c) shows that the lattice fringes with d values of 0.295 nm and 0.181 nm for the (101) and (112) planes of the ZrO2 tetragonal phase, respectively, whereas the d values of 0.243 nm corresponding to the (311) plane of the Co3O4 can be seen. The SAED pattern shown in Fig. 3(b) shows that the catalyst is crystalline in nature, and it also shows structural features supported by XRD analysis. HR-TEM analysis also confirms the tetragonal structure of ZrO2 nanoparticles. The elemental mapping shows that Co, Zr and O are homogeneously distributed. HR-TEM images of Co3O4 and ZrO2 catalysts (Figure S3, Supporting Information). SEM images depicted in Fig. 4 (a) revealed that 5.4Co3O4@ZrO2 had a flakes-like morphology. The EDS results show that the catalyst consists of only Zr, O and Co and the absence of other impurities. Elemental mapping confirmed the homogenous distribution of Zr, O and Co elements. The H2-TPR analysis of prepared catalysts is shown in Fig. 5 . Pure ZrO2 does not show any reduction peaks as it is irreducible at this temperature range. The 5.4Co3O4@ZrO2 catalyst shows a reduction at 448 °C correlated with the reduction of Co (III) → Co (II) and Co (II) → Co (0), respectively [34]. Compared to different cobalt loadings, we have seen that the reduction peak of the 5.4Co3O4@ZrO2 catalyst appears at lower temperatures due to high dispersion and smaller particle sizes [34]. Table 2 indicates the consumption of H2 during H2-TPR analysis for the prepared catalysts. The XPS spectra of the 5.4Co3O4@ZrO2 catalyst are shown in Fig. 6 . The presence of Zr 3d, Co 2p, and O1s peaks are indicated by the XPS surface survey spectra of the fresh and spent 5.4Co3O4@ZrO2 catalyst, as shown in Fig. 6(a). The XPS spectra of Co 2p core-level XPS spectra is shown in Fig. 6(b), with Co3+ 2p3/2 and Co3+ 2p1/2 have been assigned to the peaks at 780.3 eV and 795.8 eV, respectively, whereas Co2+ 2p3/2 and Co2+ 2p1/2 have been assigned to the peaks at 782.8 eV and 798.3 eV, respectively [34–36]. The energy difference between the 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 of Co2+ was 15.5 eV, which confirmed the presence of Co2+ [37]. Additionally, for Co2+ 2p3/2 and Co2+ 2p1/2, two separate satellite peaks have been found at 785.5 eV (Sat.), 788.7 eV (Sat.) and 802.05 eV, 805.6 eV, respectively [34,36,37]. Both the fresh and spent catalyst contain Co3+ and Co2+ species. XPS confirmed the presence of Co3O4 in the synthesized 5.4Co3O4@ZrO2 catalyst. The XPS spectra of the Zr 3d core level are shown in Fig. 6(c). The spin-orbit splitting components of Zr 3d were observed at binding energies (BEs) of 181.7 eV (Zr 3d5/2) and 184.1 eV (Zr 3d3/2). The peak with binding energy positioned at 181.7 eV is consistent with the Zr4+ oxidation state [28]. The energy difference between Zr 3d5/2 and Zr 3d3/2 is identical to that of Zr4+ (∆ = 2.4 eV) [33]. It was also confirmed from the XPS analysis that the tetragonal phase of ZrO2 was present in the catalyst. Fig. 6(d) shows the O-1 s core-level XPS spectra, which are deconvoluted into three peaks at 529.6, 531.3 and 532.7 eV. The peak at 529.6 eV is associated with the lattice oxygen present at the surface, whereas the peak at 531.3 eV is due to the hydroxyl group present at the surface, and the third peak at 532.7 eV indicates the presence of physisorbed and chemisorbed water [38]. Binding energies less than 531 eV are attributed to metal oxides, while hydroxides have binding energies of more than 531 eV [33]. Similarly, the same results were obtained for the spent 5.4Co3O4@ZrO2 catalyst, indicating that the oxidation states of the elements did not change during catalysis, confirming the stable nature of the catalyst. Fig. 7 shows NH3-TPD spectra of various loadings of Co3O4 on ZrO2. As can be observed, that varying cobalt loadings significantly impact the acid characteristics of the synthesized catalysts. Peaks between 50 and 250 °C are considered weak surface acidic sites; peaks between 250 and 550 °C are attributed to moderately surface acidic sites, and peaks above 550 °C are associated with strong surface acidic sites [12]. Table S2 quantifies the quantities of different groups of acidic sites present in the catalyst (Supporting Information). The 4 peaks in the 5.4Co3O4@ZrO2 sample are about 144, 272, 423, and 744 °C, showing the presence of mild and strong acidic sites on the catalyst surface. The two separate peaks at about 132 °C, 284 °C and 145 °C, 357 °C correspond to commercial ZrO2 and prepared ZrO2, respectively (Fig. 7). It can be shown that as cobalt loading increases, strong acidic sites and total acidity increases. These findings indicate that when cobalt loading increases (1.6% to 5.4%), cobalt species coverage on the zirconia surface gradually increases. According to past studies, heterogeneous catalysts based on the tri and bifunctional having Brønsted and Lewis acidic sites have been often used to obtain a high yield of adipic acid and are important for this oxidation reaction [11,12,21,39]. Pyridine-FT-IR studies of the material were carried out to demonstrate the nature of acidic sites present in 5.4Co3O4@ZrO2 (Figure S5, Supporting Information). From the pyridine IR spectra, it was observed that the band at 1451 cm−1 confirmed the presence of Lewis acidic sites, whereas a weak band at 1542 cm−1 confirmed the presence of weak Brønsted acidic sites by forming pyridinium ions [21,39,40]. The presence of surface hydroxyl groups generates Brønsted acidity, whereas Lewis acidity is generated by the presence of a vacant orbital, which can accept an electron pair [21,40]. So, the 5.4Co3O4@ZrO2 catalyst has strong Lewis acidic and weak Brønsted acidic sites. The TGA-DTG curve (Figure S6) and UV–Visible spectra (Figure S7) are provided in Supporting Information. The Raman spectra in Fig. 8 indicate that ZrO2 has a tetragonal geometry, accompanied by 6 Raman-active vibrational bands at 74, 148, 270, 382, 470, and 642 cm−1 (A1g + 2B1g + 3Eg). At 148 and 270 cm−1, B1g mode-related bands can be detected. The Eg mode was observed at 74 cm−1, whereas the A1g and the double degenerate Eg bands were observed at 642 and 382, 470 cm−1, respectively [33]. The introduction of cobalt to the support ZrO2 further modified the Raman behavior of the pure sample, which can be seen in Fig. 8. With the increase in Co-loading, bands shifting with broadening and lower intensity were noticed compared to pure ZrO2 spectra [33]. An Electron Paramagnetic Resonance (EPR) spectrum recorded at −173 °C (Fig. 9 ) characterized the freshly prepared 5.4Co3O4@ZrO2 sample, with contributions at g = 2.35, g = 2.16, g = 2.0017, g = 1.9766, and 1.9527 [41–44]. The presence of anionic vacancies, i.e., oxygen vacancies, is indicated by the signal at g = 2.0017, whereas the presence of Zr3+ ions is indicated by the signals at g = 1.9766 and 1.9527 [44–47]. A line with g = 2.16 was observed with oxygen-deficient Co3O4, and it was attributed to super exchange between Co2+ ions 3d7 (S = 1/2) induced by O2− in –Co2+−O2−- Co2+−O2- ̶ chains [41,43]. With the present freshly prepared 5.4Co3O4-ZrO2 sample, the formation of Co2+ ions (3d7, S = 3/2) tetrahedrally coordinated to four oxygen atoms could be designated by the g = 2.35 line (Fig. 9) [41,43]. These ions, however, can only be seen at very low temperatures (−173 °C) due to their extremely fast relaxation durations. As a result, the EPR line is more likely to be caused by the creation of certain Co3+(S = 0)/O2(S = 1/2) couples. Although the oxygen molecule is thermally stable (118 kcal/mol) but on the surfaces of metal oxides having oxygen vacancies, oxygen-centered radicals (such as •O2 −, •OH, and •OOH) have been observed and detected [48,49]. Because of their coordinatively unsaturated character, oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface might act as sites for molecular oxygen adsorption [21,50]. The transfer of an electron from the catalyst to the oxygen species occurs, as a result, allowing oxygen activation to occur. A proton-coupled electron transfer pathway governs the activation of oxygen at the molecular level [51]. In the case of metal oxides, oxygen radicals are generated by proton uptake and electron release in a cyclic manner [51]. Therefore, the presence of oxygen vacancies was helpful for better catalytic performance. 3.2 Catalytic activity The performances of several catalysts in transforming cyclohexane into adipic acid are shown in Table 3 . We performed a blank reaction (Table 3, entry 1) and observed that there was no conversion of cyclohexane. The commercial ZrO2 and CoO catalysts (Table 3, entries 2 and 3) showed negligible conversion. When the prepared ZrO2 and CoO catalysts (Table 3, entries 4 and 5) were employed as monometallic catalysts, they also showed little activity. The catalyst prepared by the conventional impregnation method also showed low conversion (Table 3, entry 6). The lower activity can be attributed to larger particle sizes and irregular shapes, which restrict the catalysts access to the cyclohexane. Compared to prepared ZrO2, 1.6Co3O4@ZrO2 exhibits a higher level of oxidation product, with a 6% selectivity to AA (entry 7). The catalytic activity also increases with higher Co3O4 loading (entry 6–10). The conversion climbed up to 40% with 5.4% cobalt-loaded ZrO2, while a 43% selectivity of adipic acid, 49% KA oil and 8% side products like 2,7-oxepanedione, 1,2-cyclohexanedione and cyclohexyl adipate were formed (entry 10). This finding shows that cobalt has a stronger oxidizing ability than zirconia. The standard reduction potential value explained the result, Zirconium oxide (ZrO2) has E°(V)= −1.47 (for Zr+4), but Co2+ and Co3+ have E°(V) = −0.28 V & 1.8 V, respectively [52]. Though conversion increases slightly, adipic acid selectivity decreases on increasing Co3O4 loading above 5.4% (entry 11). The decrease in selectivity with a higher Co3O4 loading of 7.7% may be related to increased particle size (Figure S3, Supporting Information). 3.2.1 Effect of reaction time We observed an increase in AA yield with increasing reaction time (Fig. 10 ). We did not find any significant increase in AA production after 8 h, indicating the reactive nature of the intermediate product (shown in Figure S8). Higher cobalt loading also reduced AA yield, likely due to increased particle size (as shown by TEM, Figure S3 Supporting Information), which lowered active metal dispersion. 3.2.2 Effect of reaction temperature The temperature was found to have a significant impact on cyclohexane conversion. When the reaction temperature was 110 °C, the catalyst showed minimal conversion; however, as the temperature increased, the conversion of cyclohexane rapidly increased (Fig. 11 ), because cyclohexanone, cyclohexanol, and cyclohexane diol are the key intermediate which was required initially to form AA [12]. When the temperature rises to 140 °C, the cyclohexane conversion increases, maybe due to the autooxidation of intermediate products like cyclohexanone [13]. We detected a decrease in AA yield, likely because of the reactive nature of the intermediate product, adipic acid ester. The optimized reaction temperature was observed to be 130 °C. When the reaction was performed at a lower temperature, the formation of KA oil was predominant (Fig. 11), with minor amounts of 1,2-cyclohexanedione and 2,7-oxepanedione. This data reveals that the kinetically generated products over the Co3O4@ZrO2 catalyst are cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone. 3.2.3 Effect of air pressure The influence of air pressure on cyclohexane oxidation was investigated in the range between 5 and 15 bar, as shown in Fig. 12 . The conversion of cyclohexane increases as the air pressure increases. When the air pressure was increased from 5 to 10 bar, the selectivity for AA increased from 32% to 43%, whereas the selectivity for KA Oil reduced from 63.5% to 49.3%. KA Oil is more likely to oxidize further to AA when air pressure increases to 10 bar. Further increase of air pressure to 15 bar has resulted in dropped in the selectivity of AA due to the formation of a more oxidized product [53]. The diffusion limitation and kinetics were performed for this reaction, similar to our earlier study [54]. The reaction kinetics reveal that the reaction is free of diffusion limitation (see Supporting Information for a detailed calculation). 3.2.4 Effect of surface acidity on the oxidative nature of Co3O4@ZrO2 nanostructured catalyst Researchers have reported a relation between surface acidity and AA selectivity in cyclohexane oxidation [12,21,39,40]. To evaluate the surface acidity, NH3-TPD studies of various catalysts (Fig. 7) and pyridine-IR of 5.4Co3O4@ZrO2 (Figure S5 (Supporting Information)) were carried out. It has been found that the nature of surface acidic sites and overall acidity can have a considerable impact on AA selectivity. Although all the acidic sites activate the cyclohexane, strong acidic sites are particularly responsible for increasing AA selectivity [12,21,39,40]. In Figure S9, the AA selectivity is plotted versus acidic sites (mmol/g) for the various catalysts. It has been observed that as the acidity increases, the AA selectivity increases. It was reported that Lewis acidic sites played a key role in enhancing the catalytic activity of the Co3O4@ZrO2 catalyst [40,55,56]. Corma et al. reported that Lewis acidic sites can accelerate oxidation processes that are dependent on substrates in two ways like electron abstraction and the formation of an acid-base adduct [56]. The oxidation product cyclohexanone and cyclohexanol were formed via CH bond activation of cyclohexane, in which Lewis acidity enhanced the catalytic activity via abstraction of an electron to form radicals in the homolytic pathway [40,55,56]. The strong acidic sites on the catalyst surface can enhance the tautomerism of the keto form (cyclohexanone) to the corresponding enol form, which is easier to activate by radical H abstraction than cyclohexanone to produce radical species to achieve the mentioned desired product AA [12,21,40]. The pyridine-adsorbed FT-IR spectra were used to evaluate the nature of the surface acidic sites of catalyst 5.4Co3O4@ZrO2 (see Fig. S5), and the catalyst was found to contain both Lewis and Brønsted acidic sites. The introduction of high valence Co-species on the surface of ZrO2 increases the number of Lewis acid sites [40]. As a result, the acidic sites and oxygen vacancies formed on 5.4Co3O4@ZrO2 were important in achieving the one-pot conversion of cyclohexane to AA. 3.3 Reusability test The true heterogeneous nature of the catalyst was studied by doing the recycling test, as shown in Fig. 13 . After the first cycle, the catalyst was collected by filtration during hot conditions, washed repeatedly with acetone, dried at 80 °C, and used for the subsequent recycling without further activation. The cyclohexane conversion dropped from 40% to 38% in the fifth cycle, whereas AA selectivity decreased from 43% to 41%, as seen in Fig. 13. The deconvoluted O1s spectra for 5.4Co3O4@ZrO2 fresh and 5.4Co3O4@ZrO2 spent catalysts (Table S3, Supporting Information) indicated a slight decrease in lattice oxygen species at the surface after five cycles could be the reason for activity loss. The XRD analysis of fresh and used catalysts (first and fifth reuse) revealed no significant differences. 3.4 Reaction mechanism The widely accepted mechanism for cyclohexane oxidation is primarily a free radical process [12,21,57]. A free radical scavenger (hydroquinone) was introduced to the cyclohexane oxidation system to confirm that this reaction is radical based using the 5.4Co3O4@ZrO2 as catalysts (Table 3, entry 12). The radical scavenger was found to have a considerable inhibitory effect on the cyclohexane reaction, indicating that it is a free-radical mechanism. Conclusions In summary, the hydrothermal process was used to synthesize the nanocrystalline Co3O4@ZrO2 catalyst, where ethylene glycol was added as a solvent and morphology controlling agent. According to the findings, loading Co3O4 in the ZrO2 matrix generated a considerable increase in acidity (1.08 mmol/g), where both Brønsted and Lewis acidic sites were present. The average particle size of Co3O4 and tetragonal ZrO2 was ∼6 and ∼10 nm, respectively. The oxygen vacancies and both the acidic sites resulted in a maximum cyclohexane conversion of ∼ 40% at 130 °C with an AA selectivity of ∼ 43% for an optimal Co-loading of 5.4 wt.% are all factors that contribute to the superior catalytic activity of 5.4Co3O4@ZrO2 nanoparticles. The catalyst was very stable and did not lose its activity even after 5 recycles, showing the true heterogeneous nature. coredata.dc:description: Despite the vast industrial importance of adipic acid (AA), developing sustainable and selective catalysts for the oxidation of cyclohexane using air as an oxidant is a longstanding challenge for researchers. We have synthesized a Co3O4@ZrO2 nanostructured catalyst and found that it converts cyclohexane to AA directly in air without adding any additional reagent. Under mild, environmentally friendly, solvent-free conditions and without any initiators, the catalyst showed a conversion of ∼40% with a selectivity of ∼43% towards adipic acid. NH3-TPD analysis confirmed the presence of acidic sites on Co3O4@ZrO2. According to the findings, loading Co3O4 in the ZrO2 matrix generated a considerable increase in acidity (1.08 mmol/g), and the trend of different loading of cobalt followed the order: 5.4Co3O4@ZrO2 > 3.2Co3O4@ZrO2 > 2.5Co3O4@ZrO2 > 1.6Co3O4@ZrO2. The catalyst was thoroughly characterized by XRD, BET, HR-TEM, SEM, H2-TPR, XPS, NH3-TPD, Pyridine-IR, TGA, Raman, ICP-AES, UV–Visible and EPR spectroscopy. The recyclability and leaching test confirmed the true heterogeneous nature of the catalyst as there was no significant loss of catalytic activity even after 5 cycles.
coredata.dc:title: Direct oxidation of cyclohexane to adipic acid in air over Co3O4@ZrO2 nanostructured catalyst
